title: Case Study: Progressive Muscle Weakness in a Middle-Aged Man with Myotonic Dystrophy
clinical_history: Mr. Simon Brown is a 45-year-old male accountant who presents with progressive muscle weakness and stiffness over the past 5 years, most prominent in his distal limbs. He first noticed difficulties in releasing his grip after shaking hands or using tools, and more recently has developed bilateral foot drop leading to frequent tripping. He reports facial muscle weakness, including difficulty smiling and mild slurred speech. On questioning, he also describes excessive daytime sleepiness and mild difficulty swallowing. Family history is positive for his mother and one maternal uncle with similar symptoms in mid-life. Neurological examination reveals myotonia (delayed muscle relaxation), weakness and wasting in the distal muscles of the forearms and lower legs, mild facial diplegia, and cataracts on slit lamp examination.
